WRITING.TEXT: The concepts of the Commonwealth vaults had a lot of potential, but the execution was god-awful.

The environment of NV was less enjoyable than those of Fo3 and Fo4, but you have to admit it was well-executed. It really did feel like a wild wild western wasteland. It's just that you and I don't like the Old West genre.
Fo4 tried for a cross between the "film-noir" and "revolutionary America" themes, which are some of my favorite genres, and I think that for the most part they failed. Nick Valentine, for example, was great in theory but poorly implemented. He was too unambiguously good to fit the mold of the detective noir antihero, and any "investigation" quests turned out to be "go here, kill everything." The lighting was often inappropriate, though to be fair I was impressed by how often they managed to produce chiaroscuro considering how difficult lighting systems can be to get right.
Overall, I think Bethesda is better at gameplay and has a lot of really good ideas about story and setting. Obsidian's concepts are less interesting, but their execution and writing are incredible.

That was a poor choice on Bethesda's part. It would have taken maybe 2 or 3 man-hours to write a conclusion for that story. Just add like 2 more terminals explaining how the residents arrived and got acclimated, and then how their society collapsed.
Instead, they opted for the vault to be unfinished when the bombs fell. It was a lazy design choice and a complete waste of a potentially good vault idea.

I'm very happy with Bethesda's improvements on the combat mechanics and leveling system. The perk chart is miles ahead of number-juggling skills, the gunplay is decent, and unarmed combat finally feels like actually punching someone to death.
But the story in Fo4 is terribly implemented. Lack of ending cards is just one of Fo4's storytelling failures. Even more striking is the lack of interesting vaults. Vaults in New Vegas and Fo3 were really some of the best parts of those games, because they gave the player a sense of exploration, discovery, and often horror.
The Commonweath has 5 vaults: 111, 114, 95, 75, and 81. 111 has a backstory, but it's very shallow and immediately apparent to the player. There is no exploration or discovery.
114 had some exposition for its story, found on terminals, but never followed through with a conclusion of what happened to it. It set up an experiment of tricking pampered rich people into living in thrifty conditions, with a crazy super-libertarian overseer, but then neglected to give me any information about how that turned out or how Skinny Malone came to occupy it.
81 was... ok. The secret was a good idea in theory, but the entire experimental subsection of the vault felt extremely linear. You can't have an authentic sense of discovery with an on-rails experience.
95 and 75 were very well done. Especially in 95, both the dark secret and the pacing of the reveal were excellent. But even 95, which was the best Commonwealth vault imo, was not as well executed as the good vaults from 3 or NV.
In Fallout 3, we had 101, 112, 87, 92, 106 and 108. Each of them had interesting stories to tell, with a beginning, middle and end to be discovered mostly at the player's leisure. They all started by instilling a sense that "something is wrong here," and provoked curiosity and encouraged the discovery of each vault's secret agenda.
New Vegas had vaults 3, 19, 21, 22, 34 and, the most brilliantly told vault story, vault 11. With the exception of 21, each of these 6 provoked the player's curiosity, and even in vaults 3 and 34 where the reveals fell rather flat. And both of those exceptions contained valuable loot, so the player did not feel as if time was wasted in exploring them.
The lack of meaningful endings was an awful design choice on Bethesda's part, and their lack of consideration for player choice (in an open-world RPG no less) made their dungeons feel way to linear for the player to really explore.

WRITING.TITLE: SPOILER I was really disappointed in one part of the main plot...
WRITING.TEXT:
Kellog's memory sequence. When Nick told me we were going to the Memory Den I was ecstatic. I was going to get to explore the troubled memories of a ruthless murderer! Maybe even relive my own memories from before the war! I was so eager to continue the quest, to see what the devs came up with, to discover more about the characters and story. In my mind, I was going into part 2 of Tranquility Lane, my favorite part of Fallout 3.
Instead, I got an on-rails sequence of boring cutscenes. Yes, Kellog's life was tragic. Yes, I was curious what happened to my son and the Institute. But it could have been done *so much better.* Tranquility Lane had me slowly figuring out the horror of a seemingly perfect world, discovering my father and the secrets in the minds of the subjects. It was engaging! And fun! But Kellog's mind made me sit through cutscenes without any interaction. That's not how you engage an audience in a video game.

WRITING.TITLE: I like myself best when I hang out with bad influences
WRITING.TEXT:
I'd really like some advice on how to handle this. See, I'm a Freshman in college, and I know this girl across the hall, lets call her T. T and I are both very introverted, and kind of dorky. Both Engineering majors, we share a lot of interests, etc. I really like her, and she likes me a lot, but our conversations always feel very forced because we each put so much value on the other's opinion. I really feel bad after hanging out with T, because I'm so painfully awkward around her that it makes me hate myself.
However, there's these other people in my hall, call them E, P, and D. These are party people. They're all Liberal Arts majors, they party every weekend and they are possessed by these petty interpersonal dramas. They're pretty much the definition of "the wrong crowd."
But they make me feel good about myself. Confident. I know I'm smarter, more responsible, more mature, more kind, and all-around better than them. They make me happy to be me. I know I'm supposed to surround myself with people I like, who will help me improve myself. But much as I hate these people, and much as they are definitely not my crowd, they like me and they make me happy.
I have no idea what to do. E and P are very happy people, whereas T is not totally satisfied. Should I hang out with E and P to learn from them how to be happy? I'm worried that I'll also pick up some things that I don't want.

WRITING.TITLE: Can I please be evil?
WRITING.TEXT:
"evil" might not be the right word for it, but... I'm in a state where I have 2 options of how to feel about the world: sad or angry. See, I can't seem to relate to other people at all. Most of the people I meet are completely unlike me, and when I do find like-minded people I realize that they make me uncomfortable. So there's a fundamental disconnect between "me" and "the rest of the world"; someone's doing something wrong here, because there's a problem.
Now, if that problem is with me, I'm going to be sad. I'm going to hate myself for being a misanthropic sociopath who can't interact with others comfortably. I'm not going to hate anyone, in fact I make a point of trying to love everyone I see. So I'm going to get anxious about making other people feel uncomfortable, I'm going to avoid pushing my problems onto others, I'm going to try to take the rational, isolationist view of the world.
But if the problem is with the world, *then* I'm going to be really fucking mad. I have this incredible pent-up rage inside me, something that I've been keeping under control for a decade. If I say that the world is wrong and I am right, I will hate everyone and everything. I will hate people who are better than me out of envy, I will hate people who are worse out of disgust. I will wish the most cruel and painful torture on every goddamn person that isn't me.
Nobody would know my thoughts, though. If I hate people, I don't care about making them feel comfortable. I'm going to talk to whoever the fuck I want because I want to, and if they feel uncomfortable then good because they all fucking deserve to. I'm going to use my acting skills to make myself appear charming and likeable without any attempt to be genuine, and if you're lucky I'll just use you as a tool and not psychologically and socially torture you for fun. If I'm angry, I'm going to hate the world and make no attempt to comply with it. It will still be controlled rage, but now I will indulge those furious desires.
I think it's wrong to be angry, to hate the world. But if I was angry I know I wouldn't care about right or wrong, logically or morally. I would just hate, and hate, universally, hate others for not conforming to my worldview, hate my worldview for not conforming to reality, hate myself for being such a sickeningly evil human being.
But *it would be so easy*. I could decide to go into "hate-mode" any moment. I'm so scared that at some point I'll snap out of this funk I'm in and look back and think "my god, I'm so ashamed of what I've done."

Thanks so much for the feedback. Your suggestion for the flagship is a huge relief, I was worried that giving them too many Mech-Inf based abilities would make them unplayably inflexible. The -1 CC is also a great idea, since it will mean the players are better off with a small empire.

WRITING.TITLE: Custom Race: The Poncho Autocracy
WRITING.TEXT:
Before the Twilight Wars, the Poncho were a very primitive tribal people. They lacked even the most basic of technologies. When a group of Hylar deserters landed on 2-Sco, they found themselves charmed by the simple Poncho, and resolved to "uplift" them from their barbaric past.
The Poncho were skeptical of the "witchcraft" the Hylar showed them, until one researcher introduced them to the concept of mechanical wheels. The Poncho were awed by the simple, elegant efficiency of the wheel. They eagerly learned all the Hylar had to offer, and within a few generations had gone from a backwards race of pseudo-sentients to a civilization that could rival the galaxy's great empires. They revere the Wheel above all things, almost religiously, as a symbol of the knowledge that showed them the light.
(Note: The backstory was kind of cobbled together, I'm mostly looking for mechanics and balance feedback.)
**Racial Ability:** Every 2 Mech Infantry on a planet increase its resource or influence value by 1
**Racial Tech 1:** (6) Your Mech Infantry may fire PDS shots
**Racial Tech 2:** (4) Each of your Destroyers may fire a pre-combat shot
**Representative 1:** (C) +1 vote for each refinery or colony you control
**Representative 2:** (S) Assassinate up to 2 representatives. You must abstain.
**Representative 3:** (C) +4 Gain 1 vote for each PDS or Mechanized Infantry unit you control
**Leaders:** Scientist, Agent, General
**Home System:** 2-Sco (3,3), 1-Sco (1,2)
**Starting Forces:** 1 SD, 3 Ground Forces, 1 Mechanized Infantry, 1 Carrier, 1 Destroyer, 1 PDS
**Flagship:** 6x3, gain 1 Trade Good for every hit by this ship
**Starting Techs:** Hylar V Assault Laser, Enviro Compensator
What do you think? They're supposed to be more of a "tall" race, who can succeed with a small number of systems if they are properly developed. I feel like the first Racial tech may be a bit overpowered, but I'm not sure how to nerf it.

Most of the answers you're getting are ludicrously biased to the left. I'm going to try to give a non-partisan explanation.
Planned Parenthood is an independent organization that provides women's health care. One of the services it provides is abortion. A large portion of the country is opposed to abortion on moral grounds (they believe it involves the killing of a human being).
However, Planned Parenthood is given federal government funding every year. Many people believe that a practice as controversial as abortion should not be funded by the federal government, essentially arguing against their tax dollars being used for what they consider murder.
On top of that ever-present controversy, there have been some videos released that caught Planned Parenthood executives talking about selling the body parts of aborted fetuses. These videos have been heavily edited, so their accuracy is subject to suspicion, but the primary claims of the videos have not been discredited.

The duty of the prosecutor isn't to convict people of crimes, it is to discover the truth and represent the state. That doesn't always mean conviction. One high-profile example is in Ferguson last summer, when the prosecutor chose to present everything to the Grand Jury when he could have sent it to court by selectively presenting the evidence. His decision cost him the publicity of a televised trial, but likely saved the state a great deal of money as well.
Defense attorneys are not bound by such high standards. Their job is to get the best deal for their clients. Whatever the defendant deserves, their attorney will try to make their situation better, with no regard to how much it might cost the state or endanger the people.
Ultimately, prosecutors serve the state and are beholden to the people they serve. Defense attorneys are beholden only to their clients.

Rebellion maybe, but rebellion against the United States? That's not something that a state should be endorsing. As for biases, the only bias I have here is for my county. Call me crazy but I think that The United States of America should have a bias towards The United States of America.

Hawaii gets a pass because it was a truly sovereign nation before it was annexed. The Maryland argument is totally nonsensical.
EDIT: And Texas had a different flag when it was the Republic of Texas. In any case, there's no problem with the flag representing something not explicitly American. It's when it endorses a violent, treasonous, clearly anti-American movement.

I know I'm going to get downvoted for this, but it has to be said. See, normally I'm all for state's rights. The federal government should mind it's own damn business and let the states do their jobs.
But the confederate flag (actually the battle flag of northern VA but whatever) is a symbol of a group of states that *actively rebelled against the Union*. It is a symbol of secession and hatred towards the United States and, ultimately, a treasonous failed rebellion. Free speech is all well and good, unless it is speech that encourages people to revolt against the US. That shit shouldn't fly.
Allowing citizens to fly flags is one thing, but states? Should we really allow states to *represent themselves with the symbol of violent anti-American rebellion?* The South lost the civil war; the CSA was never recognized and the territory it claimed was occupied by the USA. Losers don't get to fly their flags.

1. I'm not sure how narrow the language is, but there is a law that forbids payment in vouchers rather than money. It was written to check the corrupt business practices of coal companies that owned entire towns, and effectively prevented their employees from saving money.
2. I do remember one recent case where Football players at a college tried to unionize. They argued that they were *practically* employees, just not *technically*. And that the technical definition of employee was not readily applicable to their situation. A lot of it comes down to whether or not the players consider themselves employees.
3. Your RA argument is interesting, and frankly novel. I've never heard it before and it does bring up some valid points. My RA gets a paycheck, so at least at some colleges there is money being paid. I'll have to look into it, but it's a very good point.

It's not legal (or fair) for a company to pay employees with vouchers that can only be redeemed at businesses operated by the company. This is the same sort of situation. People have a right to economic freedom. By compensating athletes with "free" housing, meals and education, they deprive those athletes of their right to financial self-determination.
Employees have to be paid, and they have to be paid in *money*. By definition, and by law, money is the *only* legal tender for wages.

I don't entirely agree with you. First, I think Trump or Fiorina would give Clinton a run for her money in the general. Fiorina because she's a strong candidate (barring the track-record vulnerability) and Trump because, much as I may distrust the man, he's pretty much gaffe-proof at this point.
Second, I don't think it's at all likely that one of the current top 3 will win the primary. Trump has plurality support, but more primary voters would vote for ANYONE ELSE over him than would currently vote for him. If it comes down to Trump vs [any real GOP candidate] then Trump loses. The other two don't have nearly enough money to win a long campaign. Once the issue candidates start to drop out, the primary base will coalesce around a single establishment candidate (my money's on Rubio), who will accept the anti-establishment sentiment as warranted while reminding the people that they ought to pick a somewhat experienced person as the nominee.
What frightens me is how readily people accept the Democratic "free candy" strategy. I can respect someone whose views differ from mine, but I can't respect people blindly accepting proposals without some critical thinking. It seems to me that the people want free stuff, and some people want power enough to offer it to them, but eventually we're going to get the bill, and we won't be able to pay for it.

Individually, there are news stations with conservative biases and ones with liberal biases. However, as a whole, the "mainstream media" has a very significant liberal bias.
First, consider the major TV news agencies in the US. NBC, CNN, MSNBC, Fox News, ABC, and CBS. Only one of those has a conservative bias. And Fox News is widely (and pretty universally) regarded as an unreliable source of news. The most neutral of these stations is probably CNN, which has a mid-left-wing bias. So a citizen who wants the most neutral reporting (i.e. most citizens) has to go to a station with a *liberal* bias.
The left wing has a diversity in news reporting that the right wing lacks. They have reporting from "slightly left of center" all the way to "far-left." The right wing only has "far-right." So any viewers that are left of center are going to get their news from a liberal source. Any that are right of center, but closer to "slightly left of center" than "far-right," are going to get their news from a liberal source. The only people experiencing the conservative bias are those whose views range from "solidly conservative" to "far right."
So a greater proportion of the country receives news with a liberal bias than that which receives news with a conservative bias.

I think capitalism is fundamentally perfect, except that it makes the assumption that people are perfectly rational actors. Truth is, we're humans, and we're flawed, but we're pretty damn close to perfect rationality. So the ideal system would be to take capitalism and tweak it a bit to account for human error.

Selfish: I wish to be fluent in all human languages
Malicious: Entire leadership of the Chinese Communist Party simultaneously drops dead.
Good: Everyone is straight and cis forever (nothing against gay or trans people, but by God this would make everything simpler for everyone.)
I think they are equally likely possibilities, which is still very frightening.

Much as you may feel that Boehner was a poor Speaker, this decision to stay is good for the party. If he was going to leave when he said he would, then the election for Speaker would be a complete mess. The GOP, fractured between Tea Party and Moderates, would fail to form a consensus around a candidate. Then a handful of RINOs would throw their support behind a "moderate" Democrat and suddenly we don't have a Republican Speaker, even though we have a majority.
Like him or not, Boehner is better than a Democrat, and staying on until he has a sound successor is a good idea.

Hamilton is great, not only because it's a phenomenal show but also because the Founding Fathers were portrayed as minorities. It gives future productions a reason to cast race-blind. If all white guys had played the Founders, then future productions would ALWAYS cast white men, due to the racism and slavery issues of the time. But now any actor of any race can be justifiably cast as figures who were historically white.
While I normally don't like race-exclusive casting, I think Hamilton is a good case because it sets a precedent for the roles to be open to non white actors, and it won't exclude white actors because, let's face it, there aren't enough black and Hispanic boys in musical theatre to put on a non-white high school show.
I think Nixon would have respected him a lot if he had done it.

Textbook strawman. The Anchor Baby amendment is supported by the Tea Party, who would never endorse Arnold's candidacy (too moderate). The strategist/intelligentsia Republicans would *think about* the candidacy amendment, but wouldn't even consider an Anchor Baby amendment. The real movers and shakers in the GOP are looking for a legislative and executive immigration solution, not a constitutional one.

Nobody should be killed for their faith. His statements towards Christians could just as easily have applied to Muslims (well Sunni Muslims at least). This act of violence was not only an attack on Christianity, but an attack on all people of faith. Thank you for your condolences.

There was actually talk of a constitutional amendment to change this back when he was governor of California. He was nationally well-known, a popular governor of a normally Democratic state, and connected with the traditionally liberal Hollywood. Until that cheating scandal broke he was such a good GOP presidential candidate that the party floated the idea of *amending the constitution* to allow non-native citizens to run.

WRITING.TITLE: Any ships that focus on "suicide bomb" Zoltans?
WRITING.TEXT:
Since Zoltans deal 15 damage to everyone in a room upon death, a fun-yet-completely-impractical strategy would be to get 4 Zoltans, a clone bay, and a 4-man teleporter and board the enemy ship for the sole purpose of letting your Zoltans die and take the enemies with them.
Are there any modded ships that focus on this sort of build?

I used to agree with you, so here's the argument that changed *my* view:
Rangers need to be able to communicate with local populations in order to be as versatile as they are. Adding a woman to the squad would improve its communicative abilities immensely, especially in traditionalist cultures where men and women have very different roles in society. In these cultures, a female Ranger would be able to gather more information from female locals than a male would.

If taxpayers didn't get to choose where their tax money went, we wouldn't be a democracy.
EDIT: Weird this is the third time this has happened. I post a comment to /r/conservative, it receives an initial positive response (~10 upvotes) then after a few hours it's been reduced to negative karma. Not saying this is brigading or anything, just pointing out a pattern I observed.
EDIT2: Back to +5, it probably just fluctuates slowly on this sub.
"Compromise" is agreeing not to force taxpayers to fund procedures that fully HALF of them find morally repulsive.

I didn't buy a hat, but I did start wearing this grey newsboy cap I got in London a few years ago. I never wore hats because MFA insists that hats are a bad idea, but these past few days I've felt like "fuck it, it's raining out and I like this look."

I listen to the audiobooks. If it turns out to be one I particularly like, I will then go and read a physical copy. For Lolita, Heart of Darkness, The Man Who Was Thursday and a couple others I stopped listening to the audiobook when it became evident that this was a *really* good book.
